abstract.para: &productname; provides the tools required by Linux* users for their daily activities. It comes with an easy-to-use graphical environment, the &gnome;* desktop, that communicates with the underlying Linux system to let you access and manage files, folders, and programs. &productname; provides an integrated suite of applications for a wide range of office, multimedia, and Internet activities. It also contains the LibreOffice suite which enables editing and saving of files in a variety of formats. The office suite is available for several operating systems, meaning you can use the same data across different computing platforms.

sect1.title: Getting Started
sect1.para: When you start your system, you are usually brought to a login screen. Clicking the icon with the stylized little man in the top right-hand corner of the screen opens different accessibility settings. You can, for example, increase the contrast, switch on a screen keyboard or enlarge the font. To activate one of the functions, you must only right-click beside the slide switch. An illuminated blue i marks a currently active function.

Click your name in the middle of the login screen, enter your password and click Login. If someone else installed your system, ask your system administrator for your user name and password. You do not need to select or enter your name and password if you selected the automatic login option during installation. Either way, the &gnome; desktop will appear.

sect1.title: The &gnome; Desktop
sect1.para: The background image takes up most of the &gnome; desktop, which is initially empty. You will see a narrow black bar on the top edge of the screen. This so-called panel allows you to access all functions and applications. Specifically, it has the following elements:

formalpara.title: Time, calendar and schedule planner:
formalpara.para: The current time is ticking in the middle. When you click it, a small calendar appears which lists all pending appointments and events on the right hand side. You can call up the Time and Date Settings via the relevant buttons or start the calendar application directly (Open calendar).

formalpara.title: Volume:
formalpara.para: The icon with the loudspeaker represents loudness. The more semicircles you can see, the louder your loudspeaker becomes. You can adjust the volume by clicking the icon and dragging the top slide bar to the left or the right while pressing down the mouse button. To silence the sound, push the control all the way to the left. The loudspeaker icon will then receive a small cross. You can access additional audio playback settings by selecting the icon with the screwdriver and wrench and clicking Audio.

formalpara.title: User menu:
formalpara.para: If you click the power icon in the top right-hand corner, a menu appears from which you can manage your computer. You can adjust the screen brightness via the second controller from the top. You can access the system settings by clicking the symbol with the screwdriver and wrench on the bottom left-hand side of the screen. By clicking the lock, you can lock the screen for the duration of your lunch break. Clicking the bottom right icon allows you to shut down or restart your computer. To log out, click your username and select Logout.

formalpara.title: Activities:
formalpara.para: Clicking Activities on the top left corner of the screen takes you to the so-called activities overview where you start programs and manage those already running. You also reach this view by placing the mouse pointer on the top left corner of the screen or pressing the Windows key (also called the Super key). You return to the normal view by clicking Activities.

formalpara.title: Notifications panel:
formalpara.para: Whenever you insert a flash drive, finish downloading or some other important thing happens in your system, a corresponding message appears on the bottom edge of the screen. Some disappear quickly by themselves, others offer equally suitable actions. You can, for example, eject an inserted data CD immediately or open your content in a new window. If you do not wish to do any of the actions, simply click the title of the message and it will then disappear from the bottom edge. You can retrieve messages that have been closed or that have disappeared too early by pressing Windows M . This brings you to the notifications panel. This panel displays all of the messages that you have not responded to yet or that still apply. To display the relevant message, click the corresponding symbol. You can close the notification panel by pressing Windows M .

sect2.title: Start Programs
sect2.para: To start an application, first switch to the activities view (click Activities or press the Windows key). You now have three options:

formalpara.title: About the Dash (Favorites bar):
formalpara.para: Either click the program icon in the bar on the left edge of the screen, the so-called Dash (sometimes also inconsistently called a Dock). If you hover over one of the icons with the mouse pointer, &gnome; will tell you the name of the pertaining application.

formalpara.title: Via the applications view:
formalpara.para: If the required program is missing from the Dash, click the icon at the bottom of the Dash (the one with nine small white triangles). &gnome; will then show all the installed programs. You can scroll to the bottom of the list by clicking one of the dots on the right-hand side of the screen. To display your last used applications, click Common at the bottom of the screen. The All button displays all of the installed applications.

formalpara.title: Via the search box:
formalpara.para: You can use the search box at the top of the screen if you cannot find what you are looking for, or if you need to do something quickly. As soon as you enter a term there, &gnome; will show all the matching applications and system settings. By the way, you do not need to click the search box first, you can just simply begin typing directly.

sect2.title: Manage Window
sect2.para: After you start an application, &gnome; automatically switches back to the workplace. The name of the program and its icon appear in the panel. You can end the application by clicking it. The X on the title bar of its window does the same thing.

procedure.title: Maximize Window
procedure.para: To enlarge a window to the screen size, proceed as follows:

step.para: Bring the mouse to the title bar of the window (with the program name) and hold and press the left mouse button.
Pull the window on the top edge against the panel.
As soon as &gnome; turns the screen blue, let the mouse button go.

sect2.para: To minimize the window again, follow the same steps but vice versa: Using the mouse, pull away the title bar of the window from the top edge. Alternatively, you can also right-click the title bar. A menu with the corresponding options then appears. But beware: In contrast to other operating systems, Minimizing the window will bring you to the Activities view.

You can switch quickly between open windows via the Tab shortcut. Activities view gives an overview of all currently open windows. Clicking one of the windows there brings it into the foreground, the X symbol closes it.

sect2.title: Working with Dash
sect2.para: The small Dash in the Activities view not only keeps especially commonly used programs ready, but it can do even more: As soon as you start an application, an icon appears for it in the Dash. A light shadow underneath its icon indicates that the application is running and (at least) one window is open.

Right-clicking an icon opens a small menu which offers different actions depending on the associated program. With Add to Favorites, you can place the application icon permanently in Dash. To remove a program icon from Dash, select Remove from Favorites. If you wish to rearrange an icon in the dock, hold the left mouse button pressed above it and then drag it to its new position.

sect2.title: Using Virtual Desktops
sect2.para: &gnome; allows you to organize your program window into several virtual desktops. If you often run a lot of programs simultaneously, this minimizes the number of windows to arrange on your screen. You might, for example, use one desktop for e-mails and the calendar and another for word processing and graphics applications.

procedure.title: Move an Application to Another Virtual Desktop
procedure.para: To move an open window to another virtual desktop, proceed as follows:

step.para: Open the Activities view.
Bring the mouse pointer to the corresponding window and drag it by pressing and holding the left mouse button on the right edge of the screen.

A bar with all existing virtual desktops now opens there. Drag and drop the window to the desktop where you want it to be. In &gnome;, there is always a blank window that contains only the background image of your workspace. If you drag the window, &gnome; automatically creates another desktop.
Release the left mouse button.

procedure.title: Switch Virtual Desktops
procedure.para: You can switch between all existing desktops via Arrow up and Arrow down . Alternatively, you can also pull up the activities view:

step.para: Open the activities view (for example, with the Windows key).
Click the desired virtual desktop on the bar on the right-hand side of the screen. &gnome; now shows all the windows that are there.
Click the virtual desktop once again to finally switch to it.

procedure.title: Show Window on All Desktops
procedure.para: You can also show a currently open application on all virtual desktops:

step.para: Right-click the title bar of the application.
Click Always on the Visible Desktop.

You can also very quickly move the window to an entirely specific desktop via the small menu. To do this, select Move to Another Desktop and then the corresponding desktop. The corresponding menu item will only appear if there is at least one other virtual desktop.

sect1.title: "Perform Application" dialog box
sect1.para: Press F2 to open a small dialog box. Enter a command, for example libreoffice, and press to start the application. The command to start the application is often (but not always) the application name written in lowercase.

sect1.title: Manage Files, Folders and Media
sect1.para: Use the File Manager to create and view folders and documents, run scripts, and create CDs of your data. To open the file manager, switch to the Activities view (with the Windows key for example) and click the icon with the filing cabinet in Dash. A new window appears, displaying the content of your home directory.
The elements of the Files window include the following:

formalpara.title: Path bar
formalpara.para: Lets you find files and folders.

formalpara.title: Sidebar
formalpara.para: Lets you navigate or display information about the selected file or folder.

formalpara.title: Buttons
formalpara.para: There are several buttons in the top right-hand corner. Use the magnifying glass to activate the search function. You can use the icons to the right to switch between different display options: The icon with the lines displays the items as a list in the view window. The icon with the small dotted box displays the items as icons. Using the menu with the arrow, you can zoom in or out on the view. The button with the cogwheel brings you to another menu with additional options. For example, you can create a new folder here.

sect2.title: Handling Media
sect2.para: What happens exactly if you insert a CD or a DVD into the drive or connect a device (such as a USB stick or a removable disk) depends on the content of the medium. In the simplest case, &gnome; automatically opens file manager which, in turn, displays the content of the media. You have several options available in terms of action. A message with a corresponding selection appears on the bottom edge. You must then decide whether you want to open a DVD with a media player or in a file manager window.

If &gnome; does not respond, you must start the file manager manually. The File window lists all connected or inserted data carriers in the sidebar in the Devices area. By clicking the arrow icon on the right adjacent to its name you can eject the CD or the DVD or the connected USB stick.

sect2.title: Creating a CD or DVD
sect2.para: If your system has a CD or DVD burner, use the File manager to burn CDs and DVDs.

step.para: Insert an empty data medium and open it in the CD/DVD creator. &gnome; then opens a new File window.
Copy the desired files and folders for the CD or DVD into this window.
To write data to the CD or DVD, click Write to CD/DVD.

Change the corresponding data in the CD/DVD Creator window via Properties or accept the default settings. Then click Burn. Now there is no turning back: &gnome; will write the files onto the disk. This could take a few minutes, depending on the amount of data being burned and the speed of your burner.

sect2.para: To burn data and audio CDs, you can also use the more extensive burning program Brasero.

sect2.title: Creating and Unpacking Archives
sect2.para: If you have files you have not used recently but want to keep on your computer, you can compile and compress them in an archive file.

step.para: In the File manager, right-click the folder you want to archive and then select Compress.
Accept the default archive file name or provide a new name.

Select a file name extension from the drop-down list beside to the right. At the same time, you also determine the compression method. Use .zip if you want to forward the archive to other people or protect it with a password. In Linux the .tar.gz format is also widely used.
Enter the location where you want to save the archive file.
If you have decided to use a .zip file, you can also click Expanded Settings and enter a password there. However, remember: If you forget it, you can no longer access the content of the archive.
Then click Create.

sect2.para: To unpack an archive created in this way, right-click the file and select Unpack here.

sect2.title: Using Bookmarks
sect2.para: Use the File manager bookmarks feature to highlight your favorite folders. A matching entry then appears for quick access in the side pane.

step.para: Switch (by double-clicking) to the folder that you want to create a bookmark for.
Click cogwheel icon and select Create bookmark for this location. The bookmark is added to the list. The folder name is used as the bookmark name.
To select an item for your bookmarks list, click the required bookmark in the File manager underneath Bookmarks.

sect2.para: You can also organize your bookmark list by clicking Files in the panel at the top of the screen and selecting Bookmarks from the drop-down menu.
To change the order of your bookmarks, click a bookmark shown in the Bookmarks dialog box and drag it to the desired location.

sect1.title: Customizing your Work Environment
sect1.para: You can find more precise settings to adjust the overall appearance and behavior of your desktop in System Settings. There you can also change keyboard and mouse configurations, regional and language settings, parameters for your Internet and network usage, and more.
To call the system settings, select the power icon on the right-hand side of the (upper) panel and then click the icon with the screwdriver and wrench in the pop-up window.

step.para: Then click Background.
Click the current background image on the left-hand side.
To select a background image from the preinstalled images, just click the image and then click Select.

To add your own image, click Images. &gnome; displays all of the images from your Image folder that could be used as a background image. Images whose dimensions are too small or that appear in an unusual file format will not be available here. Click an image and then click Select.
To display a colored background, click Colors, select the color you want and then click Select at the bottom right-hand corner of the window.
You can return to all system settings using the button in the very top left-hand corner of the window.

sect1.title: Browsing the Internet with Firefox
sect1.para: Firefox* is one of the most popular web browsers. It works like all other browsers, but offers additional functions such as tools for security and data protection.
To start Firefox, switch to the activities view (such as via the Windows key) and click the icon with the globe and the fox in Dash.

Firefox awaits with all modern web technologies, such as use of tabs, pop-up blockers and download and image management. Its easy access to different search engines helps you find the information you need. Enter an Internet address (URL) in the address bar to start browsing.

To open a new empty tab in Firefox, press T or click the + sign beside the last tab. Type a new Internet address to browse. To open the page behind a link in a new tab, middle-click the link. You can change the order of the tabs by dragging and dropping them to another position. Right-clicking the tab displays a small menu. You can reload the content of a specific tab or all existing tabs, or close a single tab or all tabs, for example.

sect2.title: Finding Information

step.para: To start a Web search type the keywords in the integrated search box on the right of the address bar, then press . Firefox will display the results in the active tab.
If you want to use a specific search engine, click the icon with the small down arrow in the input field of the search bar.
Click the search engine you want, type in the search word and then press to start the search.

sect2.para: To search for words in the current website, press F . Enter your keywords in the search bar now shown on the bottom of the window. Use the buttons to the right of the search box to switch the search direction or to highlight all results in the text (via Highlight).

sect2.title: Downloading Files from the Web
sect2.para: If you download a file with Firefox, the Firefox download manager starts automatically. It then saves the file in the folder previously set in the Firefox settings. By default, it uses the Downloads folder in your home directory. To find out which files Firefox has already downloaded and how long this process took, click the down arrow to the right of the search box.

sect2.title: Configuring Preferences
sect2.para: To change the default download folder or to activate or modify the pop-up blocking feature, click Edit Settings .

You can configure advanced settings here, such as the appearance, the language, data protection and the tab options. Click the icons and set the options on each page according to your preferences. To apply the changes click Close.

sect1.title: Managing Passwords
sect1.para: &gnome; allows you to store your passwords and encryption keys in a key ring. This is particularly useful if you want to store passwords for different websites.
To create a new key ring, proceed as follows:

step.para: Press F2 and enter seahorse.
Select File New .
Select Password Key Ring and continue with Next.
Enter a name for the key ring and click OK. A new window appears.
Enter a password for the key ring, confirm the password in the input field at the bottom and click Continue.

sect1.para: You can create as many key rings as you like. For example, you can create one for private use and a second one for business. To store passwords in your key ring, proceed as follows:

step.para: Press F2 and enter seahorse.
Select File New .
Select Save password and proceed with Next.
Select your key ring, enter a description and your password.
When finished, click OK.

sect1.title: E-mail and Calendar
sect1.para: To read and manage your mails, contacts, appointments, and tasks, &productname;contains the program Evolution™, which allows you to conveniently save, organize, and call up your personal information.
With its extensive support for current communication and data interchange standards, Evolution can be used with existing corporate networks and applications, including Microsoft* Exchange.
To start Evolution, switch to the activities view (for example, via the Windows key) and click the letter icon.

If you are starting Evolution for the first time, you will be asked to answer a series of questions. The queried information is needed to set up your e-mail account and helps you import e-mail messages from your old e-mail client. It then shows you how many new messages you have and lists upcoming appointments and tasks, plus the current weather and news from news feeds. The calendar, address book and e-mail tools are available on the toolbar on the left side of the program window.

Press N to open a new item in the area of Evolution you are working in. This creates a new message in the E-mail area. Pressing N in the address book creates a new contact card and a new appointment in the calendar.
If you would like additional information about Evolution, go to Help Content in the main Evolution menu.

sect1.title: Instant Messaging with Empathy
sect1.para: Empathy is a multi-protocol Instant Messaging (IM) client. It is compatible with AOL* Instant Messenger (AIM), Google Talk, GroupWise® Messenger, ICQ, IRC, MSN Messenger, Jabber/XMPP, Yahoo!* and other networks.

With Empathy, you can log into multiple accounts on multiple IM networks simultaneously. Empathy also supports many features of the various networks, such as video chat, file transfer, away messages, and tips.
To start Empathy, switch to the activities view (for example, via the Windows key) and click the icon with the speech balloon and the blue smiley in the Dash.

A startup wizard will appear when you first launch Empathy. It will automatically offer you suggestions of other people you can find on the network. For this reason, you must populate the name, last name, and nickname fields. After you click Connect, Empathy displays all the contacts it has found in a new window (Contact list).

If you want to notify Empathy that an account is for a specific purpose, click the plus sign in the Instant message and VoIP accounts window. Select the protocol or service you want from the drop-down list at the top and enter your login details in the relevant fields. Click Add to activate your IM account in Empathy.

Add your contacts by clicking Empathy in the panel at the top of the screen and then select Contacts Add contact from the pop-up menu. However, you must be online and connected to the selected messaging service to add a contact to your list.

To start a chat, double-click the desired contact and type your message in the lower part of the chat window. Press to send the message. The upper part of the window displays the messages you have sent and received.

sect1.title: Starting &libo;
sect1.para: &libo; offers comprehensive, high-performance office programs, including a text processing program, a table calculation application, a program for creating presentations, a vector graphic program, and a database application. Because LibreOffice is available for several operating systems, you can use the documents across different operating systems.

To start &libo;, switch to the activities view (for example, by pressing the Windows key) and then click the blue document. Alternatively, type writer in the search box and press . To create a new document, click File New , and select the document type. To open an existing document, select Open, then select the file you want from the file system.

sect1.title: Viewing PDF Files and Other Documents
sect1.para: Documents that need to be shared or printed across different platforms are often saved as PDF (Portable Document Format) files. PDF files can be created using the LibreOffice suite or other applications. The &gnome; PDF viewer is called Evince. Evince can be used to view PDFs and many other document formats, such as PostScript, JjVu, DVI, and multi-page TIFFs.
To start Evince, press AltF2 and enter evince.

step.para: To view a PDF file, double-click the file you want.
Use the navigation icons at the top of the window to navigate through the document. If the PDF document contains bookmarks, you can access them to the left of the side pane.

sect1.title: Managing Your Digital Image Collection
sect1.para: Shotwell is a management tool for digital image collections. You can assign various category tags to your images. It also offers many practical image editing options. For example, you can remove red eye, crop an image to size and adjust brightness and colors. Shotwell supports all important file formats, such as JPEG, PNG, TIFF and various manufacturer-specific RAW formats, for example. With Shotwell, you can also export photos to your Flickr, Picasa or Facebook account.

To access Shotwell, open the activities view (for example, by pressing the Windows key) and then click the icon with the images in Dash. After you pass through the welcome window by clicking OK, Shotwell immediately runs through your image folder and automatically packs all the images stored in it into its library.

Shotwell shows thumbnails of the images to the right in the window. As soon as you click one of them, you can rotate it, re-edit it (enhance it) or publish it in an Internet service with the buttons on the lower edge. The side bar to the left offers different views of your photo portfolio. Provided the photos were stamped with a date, you can limit the display to photos from a specific year via Events for example.

You import new photos via File Import from Folder . Shotwell copies these photos to your image folder by default. If you want to set another folder for this, go to Edit Settings and choose the corresponding folder under Import Photos to.

sect1.title: Managing Your Music and Videos
sect1.para: Using &musicplayer;, you can import CDs, manage your digital music collection, create playlists with titles from your library, or subscribe to, download, and play podcasts. Banshee also has an Internet radio plug-in that allows you to listen to audio streams.
To open &musicplayer;, switch to the activities view (for example, via the Windows key) and click the icon with the speakers.

When you start &musicplayer; for the first time, you need to import your media to make them available in the library. Click the cogwheel and select the Add music item. The main window now displays all of the music files from the directory that is selected in the drop-down menu next to Select a location that you want to add to your library. Highlight an item and click Add title. When you have selected all music items in this way, click Close. The imported music will then appear as below:

To play a song, click Music on the left-hand side of the screen, highlight the Artist and the Album that you want and then the song in the list at the bottom of the screen. Finally, click Play. You can use the same button to stop the song. You can use the other two big buttons to play the next or previous song. Use the controller on the right-hand side to adjust the volume.
Banshee also has an integrated CD player. When you insert a CD, the CD title appears in the left panel. Click here. If you want to play a CD, highlight the first title and then click Play.

sect1.title: Logging Out
sect1.para: Once you have finished your work on the computer, you can log out and exit the system. However, you can also restart the system or shut down the computer.

sect2.title: Logging out and locking the screen
sect2.para: Click the power icon at the top right of the panel and select one of the following options:

formalpara.title: Log out
formalpara.para: By selecting your name and clicking Log out, you are logging out of your current session and will be brought back to the login screen.

formalpara.title: Lock
formalpara.para: Clicking the icon with the lock activates the screen saver. To stop this, you must click the screen and drag the mouse upwards while keeping the left mouse key pressed down. Enter your password in the input field that appears and click Unlock. This prevents unauthorized persons from working on or playing around with your computer during your absence.

sect2.title: Restarting or Shutting Down the Computer
sect2.para: You can Shut down or Restart your computer by clicking the power icon at the top right of the panel, and then clicking again on the power icon at the bottom right-hand corner.

Alternatively, you can set your computer to power saving mode. To do this, &productname; must have detected and be able to use your computer's power-saving settings. Once this requirement is met, you can click the power icon at the top right of the panel and press down the key. The power icon in the bottom right-hand corner then turns into two bars. When you click these, your computer goes into hibernation mode.
